replies.body:
Without seeing your game results it's a little hard to be too specific, but when I found I was just plain awful there's a few tips that really helped me improve.

- Firstly - learn to farm. Dear god holy shit please learn to farm. I wish someone had really made it clear when I started just how important it is to get ahead in CS in your lane (unless you're playing support, of course). Really spent time practicing your farming - go play in beginner AI games and just practice last hitting minions. So much of the time when I see someone losing lane hard it's often because they're too busy chasing kills and forgetting to farm.

It's worth realising that in early game, a kill gets you the same gold as roughly 15 minions. So instead of going all in and losing, play it a bit safer, farm up two full waves and you've basically achieved the same result.

Having said that, it mostly applies to top/ADC. In the mid lane, be less focused on perfect farm and more focused on staying in lane and getting kills when possible.

- Secondly, work on improving your overall game skills. I don't mean champion specific abilities or how to pull off the best combos - I mean things that are important no matter who you're playing as or which lane you're in. Things like farming, positioning yourself so you can make the most out of a minion wave without getting poked out, how to zone out an opponent so they can't get as much farm, when it's appropriate to back and when you should hold off, when you should and shouldn't use summoner spells, how to ward your lane and when you should stay in lane and when you should roam.

There's no easy way to just miraculously get better at those, but it helps to watch videos of people who are good. Watch footage from the OPL, or the IWCQ (which just finished), and rather than watching them fight, pay attention to how they're positioned, the importance they place on warding, etc.

- Thirdly, if you find yourself getting killed a lot, play a lot more conservatively. Like, play more conservative than you currently are, then play even more conservative than that. Your opponent can only kill you when you give them an opportunity to do so. It's up to you to find the balance between playing safe and still having lane presence for farming and kills. Practice, practice, practice.

Your overall champion skills will improve the more you play, and so will your understanding of the nuances of the game. But if you're taking in a mentality 
that you need to fight everyone all the time you're going to struggle.

In summary:

1. Practice farming
2. Learn when to push and take objectives
3. Play safe and try hard not to feed


Most of all, remember it's a fking game. You're playing it for fun. If you're not having fun, walk away for a while. Don't uninstall per se, but remember why you wanted to play it in the first place.

Either it'll get better because you get better, or you'll keep sucking and hate it forever. It's up to you which one though.

Try to avoid falling into the trap of rating your entire performance on your K/D/A. If you're a top laner who only gets 2 kills but successfully split pushes and takes out 4 turrets and an inhibitor by yourself, that's probably worth more to your team than an extra couple of kills.

I play support a lot, and even if I end up with zero kills and less than 10 assists (which happens a fair bit), if I get some deep warding in, consistently save my carry and win lane, and help my team set up for and claim mutual objectives like dragon & baron, then I'm going to call that a win.

I advise creating a second account to play simultaneously. This way, you will gain more experience (literal real life experience, not in-game 'level-up' experience) before you reach higher levels and go against better players. I was a slow learner too so that was what I did up until about level 20.

Be aware of 'botting' though, in which people use computer AI's on low-level accounts purely to level-up the account. Also watch out for 'smurfs', which are players who have high-level accounts but create a low-level account to play against worse players.

And if you really want to improve, you can watch videos of pro players. You don't need to worry about understanding what they do or say; you will learn a lot from simply watching them.

You need to buy runes and apply them to rune pages, and use the rune page during champion select.
You also need to create some mastery pages and apply masteries to use it during champion select.
Trust me, runes will help you a lot.
Anyway, what level are you right now?
At the moment you are below level 30, it is best for you to play until you get to level 30.
After you get to level 30, buy some runes, don't buy tier 2 runes because of discounts, since you will find that tier 3 runes will have better effects than tier 2 runes.
You also need to use your skills.
In Co-op vs Al, top lane will have two enemy champions, so your best bet in this case would be duo top (you and someone else go top lane), if you go bot lane, again, you need to have two champions, if you are in mid lane, you are only facing one champion, then you may be in luck, except sometimes other champions may come and gank your lane (gank means to go to a lane that may or may not be within the role of a champion).
Don't be afraid to ask for assistance when needed no matter if you are laning or jungling by using ping alerts, hold down Alt on the keyboard and left click your mouse and hold it, a menu will appear, drag your mouse to 'Assist me', then release the Alt key, and then release your mouse (at this point the chat filter will say 'LevvyLeviticus is asking for assistance'), to alert the other players, then someone should come and help you, they may reply saying that they are on their way, use the chat filter to tell your teammates that you need help is another option, but this way is more slower, and can interrupt your playing for quite a bit of time in some cases.
Try your best to do 'last hit' on minions, that is, killing a minion using either autoattacks or abilities, and this will give you gold. Use the gold to get items, such as armor, ability power, etc, these things will help you a lot.
You can hold the tab key to view all the champions, and then you can see what items they have got, getting the names of the item by simply hover your mouse to it, this way, it may give you a better idea of what you can do to counter them, like you may want to get more items, or even temporarily switch lanes.
If you are playing pvp, you definitely need the runes (I am not saying your champion is useless without runes, but runes will add customizable bonus to your champions), so buy them and apply them to your rune pages, you may even need to save up to buy additional rune pages and runes.
Often, you may want to invite your friends to play a custom game on champions that you want to learn, they can give you advice if they know how to use the champion that you want to learn.
I shall make one final point, getting only kills and assists does not necessarily mean that you will get more points, you get more points if you win, you get less points if you lose.

My first tip is to learn to farm better, learn to freeze wave, rather than aiming for overly aggressive plays when you're ahead, aim to zone your enemy out. Learn to last hit rather than shove the wave to the enemy turret, keep a vision on hand for extra vision out in the river and maximize your gold, exp gain with minimum risk. 

My second tip is learning to read your opponent. Over aggression can be a sign that the enemy jungler is coming like for example if a support is going into a 2v1 by himself but suddenly there are 2 others from the supports team popping out from the fog of war to ambush for a 3v2. Understand that when people make choices it's for a reason but also once you can get behind that reasoning you can also learn to play safer better. For example, you can reason where the jungler might start based on his champion choice or where he once was based on where he last appeared on the map and if you're overextending that he can simply walk behind you and destroy you in a 2v1 then realise that he is most probably coming towards your lane. This also applies to map awareness.

Map awareness, paying attention to the minimap and understanding the movements of your enemy team is probably the most important thing you can learn in League of legends.

The final tip I will write here for now is understanding the capabilities, of each and every champion. Knowing their abilities can help you understand exactly what a champion can do. For example, Riven's strongest power spike is at level 6, if your lane has been holding off to this point or had died some point previously you bet that Riven will be seeking an all in at level 6 and so I as a jungler might seek to sit top taking the scuttle or farming gromp.  Thresh can throw his lantern out to the jungle meaning that he can bring a jungler into the fight much faster. Shen's ult stand united can shield an ally and bring himself into the fight. Ekko's ult blinks him to his hologram (where he was 5 seconds ago) healing him and dealing AOE burst magic damage.  This also doesn't just apply to abilities but items as well because items as everyone knows give really powerful item spikes to champions who synergize with them. This information is important because it can help you not only understand the strengths and weaknesses of your enemies but also your team's strengths and how a situation may play out.


Some higher elo players might also explain that always going for flashy plays can quickly turn on you when it's so much better to make the safe decision that won't cost you.
